**Samuel "Sam" Ervin Beam**[1] (born July 26, 1974), better known by his stage
and recording name **Iron & Wine**, is an American [singer-
songwriter](/wiki/Singer-songwriter "Singer-songwriter"). He has released five
[studio albums](/wiki/Studio_album "Studio album"), several
[EPs](/wiki/Extended_play "Extended play") and
[singles](/wiki/Single_\(music\) "Single \(music\)"), as well as a few
[download-only](/wiki/Music_download "Music download") releases, which include
a [live album](/wiki/Iron_%26_Wine_Live_Bonnaroo "Iron & Wine Live Bonnaroo")
(a recording of his 2005 [Bonnaroo](/wiki/Bonnaroo_Music_Festival "Bonnaroo
Music Festival") performance). He occasionally tours with a full band.[2]

Beam was raised in [South Carolina](/wiki/South_Carolina "South Carolina")
before moving to [Virginia](/wiki/Virginia "Virginia") and then
[Florida](/wiki/Florida "Florida") to attend school. He now resides in
[Durham, North Carolina](/wiki/Durham,_North_Carolina "Durham, North
Carolina").[3] The name _Iron & Wine_ is taken from a dietary supplement named
"Beef, Iron & Wine" that he found in a general store while shooting a film.[4]

## Early
life[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Iron_%26_Wine&action=edit&section=1&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Early life")]

Beam was raised in [Chapin, South Carolina](/wiki/Chapin,_South_Carolina
"Chapin, South Carolina"), where his father worked in land management and his
mother was a schoolteacher. When he was a child, his family took regular trips
to the country, where his grandfather ran a farm. He attended Seven Oaks
Elementary School, Chapin Middle School, and Chapin High School. While home
from college, he was a waiter at California Dreaming restaurant in Columbia.
Beam earned a bachelor's degree in art from [Virginia Commonwealth
University](/wiki/Virginia_Commonwealth_University "Virginia Commonwealth
University") in [Richmond, Virginia](/wiki/Richmond,_Virginia "Richmond,
Virginia"). He specialized in painting before graduating from the [Florida
State University Film School](/wiki/Florida_State_University_Film_School
"Florida State University Film School") with an
[MFA](/wiki/Master_of_Fine_Arts "Master of Fine Arts") degree. Before the
release of the first Iron & Wine album, Beam's main source of income was as a
professor of film and cinematography at the [University of
Miami](/wiki/University_of_Miami "University of Miami") and [Miami
International University of Art &
Design](/wiki/Miami_International_University_of_Art_%26_Design "Miami
International University of Art & Design").[5] He had been writing songs for
over seven years before a friend lent him a four-track recorder. He began
making demos and gave one to his friend Michael Bridwell, brother of [Band of
Horses](/wiki/Band_of_Horses "Band of Horses") lead singer, [Ben
Bridwell](/wiki/Ben_Bridwell "Ben Bridwell"). Michael handed it to Mike
McGonigal, editor of [Yeti magazine](/wiki/Yeti_\(magazine\) "Yeti
\(magazine\)"), who chose "Dead Man's Will", later released on _[In the
Reins](/wiki/In_the_Reins "In the Reins")_ , for inclusion on one of his
magazine's compilation CDs. Beam later came to the attention of [Sub Pop
Records](/wiki/Sub_Pop "Sub Pop") co-owner, Jonathan Poneman, who contacted
Beam to propose a deal.[6][7][8][9]

## Musical
career[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Iron_%26_Wine&action=edit&section=2&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Musical career")]

Beam released his first Iron & Wine album, _[The Creek Drank the
Cradle](/wiki/The_Creek_Drank_the_Cradle "The Creek Drank the Cradle")_ , on
the Sub Pop label in 2002. Beam wrote, performed, recorded and
[produced](/wiki/Record_producer "Record producer") the album in his home
studio. Featuring [acoustic guitars](/wiki/Acoustic_guitar "Acoustic guitar"),
[banjo](/wiki/Banjo "Banjo"), and [slide guitar](/wiki/Slide_guitar "Slide
guitar"), the album's music has been compared to that of [Nick
Drake](/wiki/Nick_Drake "Nick Drake"),[10] [Simon and
Garfunkel](/wiki/Simon_and_Garfunkel "Simon and Garfunkel"),[11] [Elliott
Smith](/wiki/Elliott_Smith "Elliott Smith"), [Neil Young](/wiki/Neil_Young
"Neil Young") and [John Fahey](/wiki/John_Fahey_\(musician\) "John Fahey
\(musician\)").

Also in 2002, Beam recorded a [cover](/wiki/Cover_version "Cover version") of
[The Postal Service](/wiki/The_Postal_Service "The Postal Service")'s then-
unreleased song "[Such Great Heights](/wiki/Such_Great_Heights "Such Great
Heights")". Rather than being included on an Iron & Wine release, the track
was initially included as a [b-side](/wiki/A-side_and_B-side "A-side and
B-side") of the original version by The Postal Service. It was later included
on the B-sides and rarities album, _[Around the Well](/wiki/Around_the_Well
"Around the Well")_. He then followed up on his debut album in 2003 with _[The
Sea& The Rhythm](/wiki/The_Sea_%26_The_Rhythm "The Sea & The Rhythm")_, an EP
containing other home-recorded tracks with a similar style to the songs on the
debut.

Beam's second full-length album, _[Our Endless Numbered
Days](/wiki/Our_Endless_Numbered_Days "Our Endless Numbered Days")_ (2004),
was recorded in a professional studio with a significant increase in fidelity.
Produced in [Chicago](/wiki/Chicago "Chicago") by [Brian
Deck](/wiki/Brian_Deck "Brian Deck"), the focus was still on acoustic
material, but the inclusion of other band members gave rise to a slightly
different sound. That same year, he recorded the song "The Trapeze Swinger"
for the film _[In Good Company](/wiki/In_Good_Company_\(2004_film\) "In Good
Company \(2004 film\)")_ , and had his version of "Such Great Heights"
featured in an advertisement for [M&M's](/wiki/M%26M%27s "M&M's") and in the
film and soundtrack for _[Garden State](/wiki/Garden_State_\(film\) "Garden
State \(film\)")_. This version was later used in a 2006
[Ask.com](/wiki/Ask.com "Ask.com") advertisement, and eventually released as a
single in 2006 backed with recordings of "The Trapeze Swinger" and "Naked as
We Came" made for Radio Vienna.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/95/Sarahbeam.JPG/170px-
Sarahbeam.JPG)](/wiki/File:Sarahbeam.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Sarahbeam.JPG "Enlarge")

Sarah Beam, Samuel's sister, at the Beachland Ballroom in Cleveland

In February 2005, he released an EP entitled _[Woman King](/wiki/Woman_King
"Woman King")_ , which expanded on the sounds of his previous LP with the
addition of [electric guitars](/wiki/Electric_guitar "Electric guitar"). Each
track features a spiritual female figure, and had subtle
[Biblical](/wiki/Bible "Bible") undertones.

The EP _[In the Reins](/wiki/In_the_Reins "In the Reins")_ , a collaboration
with the Arizona-based rock band [Calexico](/wiki/Calexico_\(band\) "Calexico
\(band\)"), was released in September 2005. Beam wrote all of the EP's songs
years earlier, but Calexico added their trademark fusion of
[southwestern](/wiki/Southwestern_United_States "Southwestern United States")
rock, traditional [Mexican](/wiki/Mexico "Mexico") music and [jazz](/wiki/Jazz
"Jazz") to the songs' arrangements. Several tracks, most notably, "Burn That
Broken Bed", feature brass instruments, a first for Beam's music.[12]

The third full-length Iron & Wine album, entitled _[The Shepherd's
Dog](/wiki/The_Shepherd%27s_Dog "The Shepherd's Dog")_, was released September
25, 2007.[13] This album was voted one of the ten best of 2007 by
_[Paste](/wiki/Paste_\(magazine\) "Paste \(magazine\)")_ magazine.[14]
Contributors included Joey Burns and Paul Niehaus of
[Calexico](/wiki/Calexico_\(band\) "Calexico \(band\)"), as well as jazz
musicians Matt Lux and [Rob Burger](/wiki/Rob_Burger "Rob Burger").[15] When
asked to describe the album to _The Independent_ , Beam remarked that "it's
not a political propaganda record, but it's definitely inspired by political
confusion, because I was really taken aback when [Bush](/wiki/George_W._Bush
"George W. Bush") got reelected."[16]

Beam has released most of his music on [iTunes](/wiki/ITunes "ITunes"),
including several exclusive EPs. The _[Iron& Wine iTunes Exclusive
EP](/wiki/Iron_%26_Wine_iTunes_Exclusive_EP "Iron & Wine iTunes Exclusive
EP")_ features unreleased studio recordings, including a
[Stereolab](/wiki/Stereolab "Stereolab") cover and two tracks which had
previously only appeared on [vinyl](/wiki/Gramophone_record "Gramophone
record"). The _Live Session (iTunes Exclusive)_ features Beam and his sister,
Sarah Beam, performing a number of tracks from his albums, as well as a cover
of [New Order](/wiki/New_Order_\(band\) "New Order \(band\)")'s "[Love
Vigilantes](/wiki/Love_Vigilantes "Love Vigilantes")". Sarah Beam has
contributed backing vocals on many of Beam's studio recordings.

Beam's music has appeared in television series such as _[Grey's
Anatomy](/wiki/Grey%27s_Anatomy "Grey's Anatomy")_, _[The L
Word](/wiki/The_L_Word "The L Word")_ and _[House
M.D.](/wiki/House_\(TV_series\) "House \(TV series\)")_ "Flightless Bird,
American Mouth" was used in the film _[Twilight](/wiki/Twilight_\(2008_film\)
"Twilight \(2008 film\)")_. The song was specifically chosen for the film's
prom scene by [Kristen Stewart](/wiki/Kristen_Stewart "Kristen Stewart"), the
female lead, and appears on the [film's
soundtrack](/wiki/Twilight_\(soundtrack\) "Twilight \(soundtrack\)").

The B-sides and rarities album _[Around the Well](/wiki/Around_the_Well
"Around the Well")_ was released in 2009. Iron & Wine also contributed the
song "Stolen Houses (Die)" to the AIDS benefit album _[Dark Was the
Night](/wiki/Dark_Was_the_Night "Dark Was the Night")_ produced by the [Red
Hot Organization](/wiki/Red_Hot_Organization "Red Hot Organization").

On November 26, 2010 Iron & Wine released a special edition _Record Store Day
Black Friday_ 12" vinyl and CD single called, _Walking Far From Home_ for
independent record stores.

_[Kiss Each Other Clean](/wiki/Kiss_Each_Other_Clean "Kiss Each Other Clean")_
, Iron & Wine's fourth full-length album, was released on January 25, 2011 on
[Warner Bros. Records](/wiki/Warner_Bros._Records "Warner Bros. Records") in
North America and [4AD](/wiki/4AD "4AD") for the rest of the world.[17] With
this album, Beam blended his earlier styles with a stronger pop influence.[18]

_[Ghost on Ghost](/wiki/Ghost_on_Ghost "Ghost on Ghost")_ , Iron & Wine's
fifth studio album, was released in April 2013 on [Nonesuch
Records](/wiki/Nonesuch_Records "Nonesuch Records") in North America and
[4AD](/wiki/4AD "4AD") for the rest of the world.[19] _Ghost on Ghost_ marked
a further exploration into the pop sounds of _Kiss Each Other Clean_ while
also exhibiting jazz and R&B influences, with jazz drummer [Brian
Blade](/wiki/Brian_Blade "Brian Blade") contributing to the album.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] In
January 2014, recording during the polar vortex in Chicago, Beam and his
regular collaborator Brian Deck co-produced eight of the ten songs on
[Chadwick Stokes](/wiki/Chadwick_Stokes_Urmston "Chadwick Stokes Urmston")'
2015 album _The Horse Comanche_.[20] Beam contributed the Iron & Wine band to
the sessions and sang backing vocals.

Iron & Wine released two albums in 2015. _Archive Series: Volume 1_ , released
in February, featured unreleased songs recorded during the same period as _The
Creek Drank the Cradle_. Covers album, _[Sing Into My
Mouth](/wiki/Sing_Into_My_Mouth "Sing Into My Mouth")_ , recorded with [Band
of Horses](/wiki/Band_of_Horses "Band of Horses") singer [Ben
Bridwell](/wiki/Ben_Bridwell "Ben Bridwell"), was released in July.[21] _[Love
Letter for Fire](/wiki/Love_Letter_for_Fire "Love Letter for Fire")_ , an
album of duets with American singer-songwriter [Jesca Hoop](/wiki/Jesca_Hoop
"Jesca Hoop"), was released in 2016 on Sub Pop. Produced, recorded, and mixed
by [Tucker Martine](/wiki/Tucker_Martine "Tucker Martine"), the album also
featured contributions from [Wilco](/wiki/Wilco "Wilco")'s [Glenn
Kotche](/wiki/Glenn_Kotche "Glenn Kotche"), [Rob Burger](/wiki/Rob_Burger "Rob
Burger"), [Eyvind Kang](/wiki/Eyvind_Kang "Eyvind Kang"), [Sebastian
Steinberg](/wiki/Sebastian_Steinberg "Sebastian Steinberg"), and Edward
Rankin-Parker. [22]

In August 2017, Iron & Wine's sixth studio album [Beast
Epic](/wiki/Beast_Epic_\(album\) "Beast Epic \(album\)") was released through
[Sub Pop](/wiki/Sub_Pop "Sub Pop") Records. The record saw Beam strip back the
production and array of instruments from previous records to return to more
simple and melodic song structures.[23]

## Personal
life[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Iron_%26_Wine&action=edit&section=3&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Personal life")]

Beam, his wife Kim, and their five daughters live in [Durham, North
Carolina](/wiki/Durham,_North_Carolina "Durham, North Carolina").[24] He was
raised in the [Bible belt](/wiki/Bible_belt "Bible belt") as a Christian, but
is now an [agnostic](/wiki/Agnosticism "Agnosticism"): "That was a confusing
time for me, but I don't miss being misled. I'm not an atheist. There's an
undeniable unseen world that some people call God and think they know more
about than other people. I try not to get hung up on the names."[25][26]

In 2011, a portrait of Beam was painted by British artist [Joe
Simpson](/wiki/Joe_Simpson_\(artist\) "Joe Simpson \(artist\)"). The painting
was exhibited around the UK, including in a solo exhibition at [The Royal
Albert Hall](/wiki/The_Royal_Albert_Hall "The Royal Albert Hall").[27]
